MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Everybody thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right now, 7 am on the east coast. Trouble for technology, shares of several big tech companies under pressure yesterday, and there's fears of a regulatory crack down.

Both Facebook and Twitter are in bear market territory while Alphabet, Amazon, Netflix are in correction territory. The slide comes amid fears of a regulatory crack down following Facebook's personal data scandal.

But, the stocks are bouncing this morning we should tell you. The concerns weighed on the major average yesterday. The Dow, the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq, all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years across (ph) the month and the quarter and today.

Futures this morning show a rally at the start of trading this morning, Dow Industrials up 70 points right now, a third of a percent. S&P is up 10 points, at the third of a percent and the Nasdaq is up 40 points, that's two thirds of one percent.

In Europe, stocks are higher a across the board. Take a look, FT-100, TechCrunch (ph), DAX Index, all up this morning. In Asia overnight, green across the board there as well. Shanghai composite, the best performer in China, up one and a quarter percent.

Rebuilding America, President Trump is set to pitch his highly anticipated infrastructure plan. He's going to Ohio to do that today in an effort to fulfill a campaign promise.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, UNITED STATES PRESIDENT: We're going to make our infrastructure modernized, and we're really way behind schedule. We're way behind other countries. We also led the many way for many, many years. Then a number of decades ago it slowed down, and over the last eight years and 15 years, to be honest, it's come to a halt.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: What to expect from the big push coming up this morning. Collusion in the Capitol, newly uncovered texts show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI, the Justice Department, and the Democratic Leadership over the Russia investigation. They were all in on it. The shocking revelations coming up.

Let's make a deal. Nissan reportedly in talks to merge with Renault. We are breaking down the deal for the two auto companies, which have been partnered side by side for some time now. And not funny, comedian Jim Carrey under fire again this morning after his latest painting targets the president's son. The outrage coming up this morning.

And then problems in the bedroom, why nearly one-third of married couples are ready to hit the snooze button on their sleeping arrangements. All those stories coming up this morning. Joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McdDowell, Forbes Media Chairman and the former Republican President Trump Candidate himself, Steve Forbes is here. CRFA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell as well. Good morning, everybody. Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, good morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Here on a day that we're ending the quarter, which is going to be a pretty good quarter for earnings, by the way.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CRFA: It's going to be a great aware for earnings, not so much for the performance of the stock market. But once earnings start being released, April 13th, JP Morgan really kicks it all off. We should see investors feel reassured about the fundamentals of corporate America.

BARTIROMO: Because you're expecting 16.5% earnings growth in the S&P 500 in the first quarter, right?

MCDOWELL: I think one thing weighing on the market, and we were talking about this in the break, and we mentioned it in the last hour. It's not just Facebook and regulatory risk at some of these technology companies. We'll also look at Tesla. I think Tesla's stock fell more than 7.5% just yesterday. The unsecured bonds that mature in 2025, you mentioned this, fell to 86 cents on dollar. Although they recovered two cents of that 88 cents before ticking up to that. That is a real concern with the burn rate. Tesla was $1 billion a quarter recently. They're trying to get production rolling of the model 3. That's a real concern. Again I think that is another canary that we need to watch.

BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right.

FORBES: Uncertainty about a trade war too.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: Which thankfully it looks like it may be tamping down a little bit.

BARTIROMO: The trade war worries?

FORBES: Worries --

BARTIROMO: Yes. On your point, Dagen, cover story on the business section, Tesla, first it was the stock that traded down. Now we're worried about the bonds, because that's really showing liquid at this worries.

MCDOWELL: We're nerds. We watch the debt. The equity doesn't really tell you the story. Again financial crisis in - leading up to 2008, it was all in and in the bonds for two years before the market really collapsed.

BARTIROMO: I've got to give a shout out to Zero Hedge, they did a very good job on this a couple of days ago before this really came out. Now we're seeing it all over the place. You were saying the trade war worries are fading, because people look at it now as a real negotiation opening bid on the president's part, don't they?

FORBES: Yes, the South Korea deal we'll be discussing later, tampering but not much change.

BARTIROMO: Yes that's what Mary Kiesel (ph) said yesterday. We're going to talk with Peter Navarro about that coming up. But first there's this, President Trump is headed to Ohio this afternoon to talk about his $1.5 trillion plan on fixing America's roads and bridges. The pitch coming as his proposal appears to be stalled in Congress with some lawmakers concerned that state and local governments are responsible for the bulk of the spending. Here's a look back to what President Trump said about rebuilding our nation's infrastructure at his State Of The Union Address back in January.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: America is a nation of builders. We built the Empire State building in just one year. Isn't is a disgrace that it can now take 10 years just to get a minor permit approved for the building of a simple road? I'm asking both parties to come together to give us safe, fast, reliable, and modern infrastructure that our economy needs and our people deserve.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: The White House Council of Economic Advisors estimates that Trump's plan could add between 290,000 to 414,000 infrastructure jobs over the next 10 years. Joining us right now is the Great America PAC Chairman, former Reagan Chief White House Political Advisor, and Fox News Contributor -

ED ROLLINS, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you, good morning.

BARTIROMO: Ed Rollins. Ed, Good to see you. What do you expect the president to talk about today? Obviously money is tight. Where does the money come from for this infrastructure plan?

ROLLINS: Obviously it's a balance between federal investment and private investment and state. This should have been priority number one. If this would have gone up instead of the healthcare in the beginning, I think we would have had a big bill today. The problem today is I don't think we're going to have much after the big budget bill.

So I think until the Congress re-votes itself, in or out, I don't think we'll see much until January. The biggest problem here is the federal government's always put the biggest chunk in -- 80% on the highway bills (inaudible). He's talking about 20% today. A lot of these states and local communities don't have the resources. We don't have the resources at the federal level to do what we should do. And trying to get the private investment in there is going to be very important.

BARTIROMO: The president, Dagen, wants $200 billion in federal money and then the rest of the $1.5 trillion to come from the private sector.

MCDOWELL: By the way, though, Ed, there was $21 billion in new infrastructure spending that was in that -

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- that omnibus bill -- that spending bill that the president acted like he was going to veto it and didn't. So there's --

ROLLINS: There's -

MCDOWELL: -- there are hands-out to construction in there.

ROLLINS: The problem always when you -- my first experience in Washington was the assistant secretary congressional (inaudible) department of transportation. Every member has their own special projects that they want. My sense is democrats, at this point in time, will do nothing to make the president look good. I do think they want this bill. I think it's not going to get done until at least January or February of next year.

FORBES: Is there any way with executive orders - or even in the transportation department, to remove the barriers, licensing barriers, permit barriers?

ROLLINS: I think that's very, very important.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's the big issue.

ROLLINS: As you know well and Elaine Chao is as capable as anybody in this administration. My assumption is she's not going to get a tweet firing her in the foreseeable future. I think she can basically push a lot of this stuff. I think it's going to be a slow walk, it doesn't really need to be a fast walk from the get-go. It will create jobs. It will be a coalition because labor unions, what have you, all want these jobs. So democrats should be at the forefront of this, and they're basically stalling it. I think what they're going to try and do is split it into multi-bills, sewage type bills, highway bills, what have you as opposed to a big comprehensive bill.

MCDOWELL: Who is going to pay for it though? This is my - this goes back to my issue, that, again, when you don't have the federal gas tax, when it hasn't gone up in more than 20 years, and then you expect what -- regular income taxpayers to pay for this? We're going to borrow it? Again, there's no financial responsibility in Washington.

ROLLINS: Well the last time you raised the gas tax, George Mitchell was the Senate Majority Leader back in 1991 and 1992.

FORBES: And then moreover, they've been using the gas tax for non-highway spending.

ROLLINS: Non-highway types things. So it's a big -

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: Trail (ph) of the original trust -

(CROSSTALK)

BELL: How do you -

ROLLINS: Go ahead.

BELL: How do you get private investment to come in, make this attractive to them to --

BARTIROMO: Well they all want in. I think a lot of private - well go ahead, Ed.

ROLLINS: I feel the same way. I think if you have a real plan, and you see that the state and local and the federal government are going to coordinate and speed this process up, they'll put money in. If - but there's -- that piece of it's not done yet.

BARTIROMO: People are not going to invest in infrastructure if they think they won't get a return for 13 years.

ROLLINS: Absolutely. I think -

BARTIROMO: That's one of the issues. They've got to roll back the regulations and the barriers and the red tape, and then I think they'll get the investment, don't you think, Ed?

ROLLINS: Absolutely, and I think it's a high priority. And, again, it should have been the first priority. It should have been bill number one. And it wasn't, and now we have to wait on it --

FORBES: Do you think at the local level there will be blowback on having toll roads instead of supposed (ph) free roads?

ROLLINS: There is, but at the end of the day I think there's such a frustration at this point in time the old term free highways - or -- is just not possible.

FORBES: Free potholes.

BARTIROMO: When I interviewed Jamie Dimon back in January, one of the things he said was "I tried to invest," and he was looking at the Bayonne Bridge, Bayonne New Jersey and Staten Island.

ROLLINS: Right.

BARTIROMO: The bridge crossing and it was going to take 13 years. That's when his team said "You know what, let's put this aside right now." We've got to get to The White House shake up Ed., because Veterans Affairs Secretary David Shulkin is now out. The latest to leave the Trump Administration with position to the president, and Ronnie Jackson tapped to replace him. Your thoughts, Ed? Shulkin is the second cabinet member to be fired just this month.

ROLLINS: He was an Obama holdover. He was, as you remember, was the unanimous appointment. I don't think he was a Trump guy from the beginning. He obviously self-destructed by his inconsistencies on following government regulations. The Admiral will be a unique choice. He made a brilliant decision in saying that the president weighed 239 pounds as opposed to 249 pounds, which would've put him in the obese category.

(LAUGHTER)

ROLLINS: So he's (inaudible) enough to know that. My sense is he's going to be a great outside spokesman. He's an admiral, he's a surgeon, and at this point in time it's one of the president's priorities, and he'll have the president's ear which is very important. Where I don't think the present secretary had the ear.

MCDOWELL: You know what I was thinking about, though, with the announcement of Shulkin, which was expected, people - again the headlines are always more White House chaos. And I thought to myself, maybe president Trump is actually firing people who deserve to be fired and in past administrations people hung around too long, because the president and their advisors were always reticent to make it look like we made a bad hire, we made a bad choice but this guy stinks, he's gone.

ROLLINS: I think you're right. The fact that he had been in an administration as the Deputy Secretary, he knew what the rules and regulations were. You don't take free tickets to Wimbledon. You don't go fly your wife all over the world on a -

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Who gave them to you? Umm (ph).

BELL: He's a really good friend, but I forgot his name.

ROLLINS: It's amazing this keeps coming up. Tom Price, former Health Secretary.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right. Why does this keep coming up? You're absolutely right.

ROLLINS: The bottom line -- one of the jobs I had when I was in The White House is I would be the last person to talk to the cabinet officers. I'd say here there's rules and regulations. Read those basically and abide by them. If you have any doubt, call your Counsel - call Fred Fielding who was our Counsel. And you followed those rules. If you don't follow those rules, you're done. Just understand that. You're going to get over there. You're going to think you're imperial (ph), because you've got big offices and all the rest of it. urn:contentItem:5S0K-7GY1-DY0W-418T-00000-00Facebook Privacy Settings; Mark Zuckerberg to go in Front of Congress; Trump in Ohio for Infrastructure; Gronkowski's Next Movie; Obama's White House Coordinated With Russia?; Carnival Cruise Wants 15 Year Old Boy's Snapchat Handle; Lebron James Averages 10 Points Per Game Since 20072018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:31ZLexisNexisFacebook Privacy Settings; Mark Zuckerberg to go in Front of Congress; Trump in Ohio for Infrastructure; Gronkowski's Next Movie; Obama's White House Coordinated With Russia?; Carnival Cruise Wants 15 Year Old Boy's Snapchat Handle; Lebron James Averages 10 Points Per Game Since 2007LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Everybody thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right now, 7 am on the east coast. Trouble for technology, shares of several big tech companies under pressure yesterday, and there's fears of a regulatory crack down.

Both Facebook and Twitter are in bear market territory while Alphabet, Amazon, Netflix are in correction territory. The slide comes amid fears of a regulatory crack down following Facebook's personal data scandal.

But, the stocks are bouncing this morning we should tell you. The concerns weighed on the major average yesterday. The Dow, the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq, all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years across (ph) the month and the quarter and today.

Futures this morning show a rally at the start of trading this morning, Dow Industrials up 70 points right now, a third of a percent. S&P is up 10 points, at the third of a percent and the Nasdaq is up 40 points, that's two thirds of one percent.

In Europe, stocks are higher a across the board. Take a look, FT-100, TechCrunch (ph), DAX Index, all up this morning. In Asia overnight, green across the board there as well. Shanghai composite, the best performer in China, up one and a quarter percent.

Rebuilding America, President Trump is set to pitch his highly anticipated infrastructure plan. He's going to Ohio to do that today in an effort to fulfill a campaign promise.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, UNITED STATES PRESIDENT: We're going to make our infrastructure modernized, and we're really way behind schedule. We're way behind other countries. We also led the many way for many, many years. Then a number of decades ago it slowed down, and over the last eight years and 15 years, to be honest, it's come to a halt.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: What to expect from the big push coming up this morning. Collusion in the Capitol, newly uncovered texts show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI, the Justice Department, and the Democratic Leadership over the Russia investigation. They were all in on it. The shocking revelations coming up.

Let's make a deal. Nissan reportedly in talks to merge with Renault. We are breaking down the deal for the two auto companies, which have been partnered side by side for some time now. And not funny, comedian Jim Carrey under fire again this morning after his latest painting targets the president's son. The outrage coming up this morning.

And then problems in the bedroom, why nearly one-third of married couples are ready to hit the snooze button on their sleeping arrangements. All those stories coming up this morning. Joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McdDowell, Forbes Media Chairman and the former Republican President Trump Candidate himself, Steve Forbes is here. CRFA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell as well. Good morning, everybody. Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, good morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Here on a day that we're ending the quarter, which is going to be a pretty good quarter for earnings, by the way.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CRFA: It's going to be a great aware for earnings, not so much for the performance of the stock market. But once earnings start being released, April 13th, JP Morgan really kicks it all off. We should see investors feel reassured about the fundamentals of corporate America.

BARTIROMO: Because you're expecting 16.5% earnings growth in the S&P 500 in the first quarter, right?

MCDOWELL: I think one thing weighing on the market, and we were talking about this in the break, and we mentioned it in the last hour. It's not just Facebook and regulatory risk at some of these technology companies. We'll also look at Tesla. I think Tesla's stock fell more than 7.5% just yesterday. The unsecured bonds that mature in 2025, you mentioned this, fell to 86 cents on dollar. Although they recovered two cents of that 88 cents before ticking up to that. That is a real concern with the burn rate. Tesla was $1 billion a quarter recently. They're trying to get production rolling of the model 3. That's a real concern. Again I think that is another canary that we need to watch.

BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right.

FORBES: Uncertainty about a trade war too.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: Which thankfully it looks like it may be tamping down a little bit.

BARTIROMO: The trade war worries?

FORBES: Worries --

BARTIROMO: Yes. On your point, Dagen, cover story on the business section, Tesla, first it was the stock that traded down. Now we're worried about the bonds, because that's really showing liquid at this worries.

MCDOWELL: We're nerds. We watch the debt. The equity doesn't really tell you the story. Again financial crisis in - leading up to 2008, it was all in and in the bonds for two years before the market really collapsed.

BARTIROMO: I've got to give a shout out to Zero Hedge, they did a very good job on this a couple of days ago before this really came out. Now we're seeing it all over the place. You were saying the trade war worries are fading, because people look at it now as a real negotiation opening bid on the president's part, don't they?

FORBES: Yes, the South Korea deal we'll be discussing later, tampering but not much change.

BARTIROMO: Yes that's what Mary Kiesel (ph) said yesterday. We're going to talk with Peter Navarro about that coming up. But first there's this, President Trump is headed to Ohio this afternoon to talk about his $1.5 trillion plan on fixing America's roads and bridges. The pitch coming as his proposal appears to be stalled in Congress with some lawmakers concerned that state and local governments are responsible for the bulk of the spending. Here's a look back to what President Trump said about rebuilding our nation's infrastructure at his State Of The Union Address back in January.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: America is a nation of builders. We built the Empire State building in just one year. Isn't is a disgrace that it can now take 10 years just to get a minor permit approved for the building of a simple road? I'm asking both parties to come together to give us safe, fast, reliable, and modern infrastructure that our economy needs and our people deserve.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: The White House Council of Economic Advisors estimates that Trump's plan could add between 290,000 to 414,000 infrastructure jobs over the next 10 years. Joining us right now is the Great America PAC Chairman, former Reagan Chief White House Political Advisor, and Fox News Contributor -

ED ROLLINS, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Thank you, good morning.

BARTIROMO: Ed Rollins. Ed, Good to see you. What do you expect the president to talk about today? Obviously money is tight. Where does the money come from for this infrastructure plan?

ROLLINS: Obviously it's a balance between federal investment and private investment and state. This should have been priority number one. If this would have gone up instead of the healthcare in the beginning, I think we would have had a big bill today. The problem today is I don't think we're going to have much after the big budget bill.

So I think until the Congress re-votes itself, in or out, I don't think we'll see much until January. The biggest problem here is the federal government's always put the biggest chunk in -- 80% on the highway bills (inaudible). He's talking about 20% today. A lot of these states and local communities don't have the resources. We don't have the resources at the federal level to do what we should do. And trying to get the private investment in there is going to be very important.

BARTIROMO: The president, Dagen, wants $200 billion in federal money and then the rest of the $1.5 trillion to come from the private sector.

MCDOWELL: By the way, though, Ed, there was $21 billion in new infrastructure spending that was in that -

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: -- that omnibus bill -- that spending bill that the president acted like he was going to veto it and didn't. So there's --

ROLLINS: There's -

MCDOWELL: -- there are hands-out to construction in there.

ROLLINS: The problem always when you -- my first experience in Washington was the assistant secretary congressional (inaudible) department of transportation. Every member has their own special projects that they want. My sense is democrats, at this point in time, will do nothing to make the president look good. I do think they want this bill. I think it's not going to get done until at least January or February of next year.

FORBES: Is there any way with executive orders - or even in the transportation department, to remove the barriers, licensing barriers, permit barriers?

ROLLINS: I think that's very, very important.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's the big issue.

ROLLINS: As you know well and Elaine Chao is as capable as anybody in this administration. My assumption is she's not going to get a tweet firing her in the foreseeable future. I think she can basically push a lot of this stuff. I think it's going to be a slow walk, it doesn't really need to be a fast walk from the get-go. It will create jobs. It will be a coalition because labor unions, what have you, all want these jobs. So democrats should be at the forefront of this, and they're basically stalling it. I think what they're going to try and do is split it into multi-bills, sewage type bills, highway bills, what have you as opposed to a big comprehensive bill.

MCDOWELL: Who is going to pay for it though? This is my - this goes back to my issue, that, again, when you don't have the federal gas tax, when it hasn't gone up in more than 20 years, and then you expect what -- regular income taxpayers to pay for this? We're going to borrow it? Again, there's no financial responsibility in Washington.

ROLLINS: Well the last time you raised the gas tax, George Mitchell was the Senate Majority Leader back in 1991 and 1992.

FORBES: And then moreover, they've been using the gas tax for non-highway spending.

ROLLINS: Non-highway types things. So it's a big -

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: Trail (ph) of the original trust -

(CROSSTALK)

BELL: How do you -

ROLLINS: Go ahead.

BELL: How do you get private investment to come in, make this attractive to them to --

BARTIROMO: Well they all want in. I think a lot of private - well go ahead, Ed.

ROLLINS: I feel the same way. I think if you have a real plan, and you see that the state and local and the federal government are going to coordinate and speed this process up, they'll put money in. If - but there's -- that piece of it's not done yet.

BARTIROMO: People are not going to invest in infrastructure if they think they won't get a return for 13 years.

ROLLINS: Absolutely. I think -

BARTIROMO: That's one of the issues. They've got to roll back the regulations and the barriers and the red tape, and then I think they'll get the investment, don't you think, Ed?

ROLLINS: Absolutely, and I think it's a high priority. And, again, it should have been the first priority. It should have been bill number one. And it wasn't, and now we have to wait on it --

FORBES: Do you think at the local level there will be blowback on having toll roads instead of supposed (ph) free roads?

ROLLINS: There is, but at the end of the day I think there's such a frustration at this point in time the old term free highways - or -- is just not possible.

FORBES: Free potholes.

BARTIROMO: When I interviewed Jamie Dimon back in January, one of the things he said was "I tried to invest," and he was looking at the Bayonne Bridge, Bayonne New Jersey and Staten Island.

ROLLINS: Right.

BARTIROMO: The bridge crossing and it was going to take 13 years. That's when his team said "You know what, let's put this aside right now." We've got to get to The White House shake up Ed., because Veterans Affairs Secretary David Shulkin is now out. The latest to leave the Trump Administration with position to the president, and Ronnie Jackson tapped to replace him. Your thoughts, Ed? Shulkin is the second cabinet member to be fired just this month.

ROLLINS: He was an Obama holdover. He was, as you remember, was the unanimous appointment. I don't think he was a Trump guy from the beginning. He obviously self-destructed by his inconsistencies on following government regulations. The Admiral will be a unique choice. He made a brilliant decision in saying that the president weighed 239 pounds as opposed to 249 pounds, which would've put him in the obese category.

(LAUGHTER)

ROLLINS: So he's (inaudible) enough to know that. My sense is he's going to be a great outside spokesman. He's an admiral, he's a surgeon, and at this point in time it's one of the president's priorities, and he'll have the president's ear which is very important. Where I don't think the present secretary had the ear.

MCDOWELL: You know what I was thinking about, though, with the announcement of Shulkin, which was expected, people - again the headlines are always more White House chaos. And I thought to myself, maybe president Trump is actually firing people who deserve to be fired and in past administrations people hung around too long, because the president and their advisors were always reticent to make it look like we made a bad hire, we made a bad choice but this guy stinks, he's gone.

ROLLINS: I think you're right. The fact that he had been in an administration as the Deputy Secretary, he knew what the rules and regulations were. You don't take free tickets to Wimbledon. You don't go fly your wife all over the world on a -

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Who gave them to you? Umm (ph).

BELL: He's a really good friend, but I forgot his name.

ROLLINS: It's amazing this keeps coming up. Tom Price, former Health Secretary.

BARTIROMO: Yes, right. Why does this keep coming up? You're absolutely right.

ROLLINS: The bottom line -- one of the jobs I had when I was in The White House is I would be the last person to talk to the cabinet officers. I'd say here there's rules and regulations. Read those basically and abide by them. If you have any doubt, call your Counsel - call Fred Fielding who was our Counsel. And you followed those rules. If you don't follow those rules, you're done. Just understand that. You're going to get over there. You're going to think you're imperial (ph), because you've got big offices and all the rest of it. At the end of the day, you've got to basically reverse taxpayers' dollars and it's a position of trust.

BELL: It's not your money.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Guys, more ugliness from Hollywood. Jim Carrey is slamming President Trump again. The actor tweeted a drawing of what appears to be the president's sons being attacked by an elephant. The caption says #teamelephant. Jim Carrey has posted other pictures. He bashed other people like White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders. What's your take on this?

ROLLINS: My take is he's totally irrelevant today. He was a big movie star 20 years ago, 15 years ago, he hasn't made a buck they a movie in a long, long time. Political commentary (ph) cartoonists and always vicious. And this guy who's talentless, trying to basically be outrageous is being vicious.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

ROLLINS: And we shouldn't make a big deal out of it.

FORBES: We used to have a show called "Hollywood Squares" where washed up actors would go --

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: You're right.

FORBES: Maybe he should resurrect that.

(CROSSTALK)

ROLLINS: I didn't think he was funny when --

MCDOWELL: Now Paul Lynde was never washed up, he was awesome. He was the famous center (ph) square, so I'm just putting him back on that (ph).

(LAUGHTER)

ROLLINS: It's good to know all of this stuff is not relevant to the ordinary people who are 18 and 19 years old anymore.

BARTIROMO: Jim Carrey, you're irrelevant, that's the bottom line.

ROLLINS: Well, you know, I always thought in the next life - I'm now 75, I'd be a political cartoonist, because you get to get up everyday and slam somebody and a not pay a consequence. I think he will pay a consequence for this.

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll leave it there. Ed, it's great to see you.

ROLLINS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Ed Rollins. Coming up, new FBI bombshell. Newly uncovered texts show possible coordination between the Obama Administration and all the agencies, CIA, FBI, Just Department, Democratic leadership as well in Congress on the Russia Investigation. The outrage coming up. And then until sleep do us part? A new survey, wait until you see what this says

(BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Looks like it will be a good open, this the final day of the quarter and the month for certainly markets and businesses concerned. Dow Industrials expected to be up 70 points this morning at the start of trading, up a third of a percent. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 are also higher. Meanwhile, there's this, a slide in big technology stocks affecting many investors as companies gain more influence in the global stock markets. Cheryl Casone has headlines now, Cheryl?

CASONEl: Looking for those good earnings reports, Maria, from these guys you know after the slide in their stocks for the month of March. It has Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google parent Alphabet, Apple, Microsoft, nearly all of these guys losing ground yesterday, in particular with Facebook now sitting in bear market territory and Alphabet, Netflix and Amazon in correction territory. Technology stocks have been under fire over concerns of more regulatory oversight following the revelations over Facebook's misuse of user data. President Trump reportedly, again, suggesting that he might seek to change Amazon's tax status. So we hope the earnings are good, because the stocks have been hit this month. Well, a car merger reportedly is in the works this morning. Reports are saying that France's Renault is in talks with Japan's Nissan. A get together would build on the strategic alliance that the companies have actually had since 1999. Taking a look at shares of Renualt, it's up 13% so far this year.

British police say a former Russian spy and his daughter first came into contact with a nerve agent at their own front door. Authorities there are now focusing their investigation in and around their home. They're also searching for a person who could have delivered the poison to them. London of course blames Moscow for the attack, triggering a major diplomatic dispute between Russia and several Western countries including the United States.

And get this, nearly one-third of Americans want to file for sleep divorce from their partners. That's according to a brand new survey. That's a lot more than the study back in 2010, that found that one-quarter of couples have separate sleeping arrangements. But now it seems that some uncomfortable sleepers are afraid to bring up the idea of different beds. So let's just get a divorce. Here's another crazy stat of the 3,000 people surveyed, 300 say they've ended a previous relationship because of sleep issues. There you have it, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Don't get in the middle of my sleep time.

CASONE: You need your sleep. And if you can't get on board with that, buddy, see you.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. Thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: You bet.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Facebook is under fire. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook says some big changes are needed at Facebook and needed fast. This comes as Facebook users scramble to protect themselves without waiting for regulatory crack downs. Then, Carnival Cruise Lines making a huge offer to a teenager for his Snapchat handle, even getting Shaquille O'Neal in on the action. Now the teen is sailing away with a win. The story coming up. Back in a moment

(BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

TIME COOK, CEO, APPLE: We care about the user experience, and we're not going to traffic in your personal life. I think it's an invasion of privacy. I think it's - privacy to us is a human right, it's a civil liberty.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: That was Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, doubling down on his company's commitment to protecting user privacy. The comments come as the technology community remains under fire following Facebook's data scandal, which now sees several technology executives including Mark Zuckerberg being called to testify before congress. Joining us is the cyber guy, Kurt Knudsen (ph). Kirk, thanks for weighing in here. This scandal around Facebook has people scrambling to figure out how to protect their personal data. What can we do?

KURT KNUDSEN (ph): Maria, so true. Good morning to you. We're talking about it also, and how about Tim Cook? Does he not smell like a rose this morning in the manure of Silicon Valley? I think he's just trying to stay out of it. Facebook, though, not so lucky. Things you can do right now with your own devices. Six must do changes just to reign in a little bit of your privacy. Number one, you can turn off the ability for apps to have access to the data. I was shocked when I went to my own settings -- you simply remove the apps on Facebook. I went to my own settings and I saw 74 apps, about half of which I never even remembered giving access to my life, and they have it.

Also, set alerts so if your Facebook is logged on at another location or another device that you're familiar with, it's going to let you know. And then disable the Facebook integration. It's so easy to use this where you log onto other websites and instead of putting in all of the form, you just log on with Facebook. But what we now know, that we didn't really know very clearly before, is that they're using that as a path to, again, share our personal data.

So the list goes on. Limiting access to the apps that you use, location privacy, turning that off as well as the history which is like the bread crumbs of everywhere you go, and then number one thing, tell your friends to do these same settings, because you're vulnerable to what your friends allow through also. So if they can see what's on your profile, Maria, they're also going to see access to being able to carry that data away and give it to a third party app.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean we were all doing this ourselves the other day, looking at our apps to try to figure out what's open and what isn't. You have to go into Facebook and then there's another area just for the apps, right, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Right. They're trying to basically make changing your privacy settings easier. That was one of the announcements yesterday. But again, it's never been clear. And that's really the whole point, is over the years Facebook has asked you for more and more of your personal information, just down to even the most granular detail about where you went to elementary school. And what do they do? They slice it and dice it and let these app developers in to access it. And you really don't know what's going on.

BARTIROMO: That is so wrong.

MCDOWELL: And then so what the alternative is, if you want to delete your profile, Kurt, they don't make it that easy either. Your history is still - -

KNUDSEN (ph): No one's going to do that, I'm sorry.. You've got Elon Musk over in California, big drama (ph) answering some removing myself as well as the companies off of Facebook. No one is going to really do that. That's not a practical solution. The practical solution may be taking a look at the leadership at Facebook and saying by now, after all of thee flaws, one after another and the messes that Facebook has, especially related to personal data, you have Mark Zuckerberg who always is reluctant to show face, he comes out, he makes a big grand corrective gesture and then you see about a 5% action of what he said would be some spectacular new direction. I'm soft on him. I don't like what the company's done. I think he's a spectacular human being, great leader, love what he built. But I think they need a grown-up inside of Facebook. They're clearly not out for our interests. They're out to serve themselves, to grow their platform and to make money off of apps (ph) --

BARTIROMO: He's not going anywhere.

FORBES: Kurt (ph) - can he -- he's going to be testifying to Congress. Can he finally settle this in congress and say here's what we're doing?

KNUDSEN (ph): Not a chance. Two weeks from now, he's due to show up. There's no way. I'm sorry. Again, that's just going to be theater on his part. There's something very awkward about him in the public, whether he's on camera or he's at a group. That's probably why they kept him, and he's kept himself from being in public forums. He's not the best communicator.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Well there's -

KNUDSEN (ph): Put Sheryl Sandberg up there, there might be a different story.

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: -- testimony --

MCDOWELL: There's a Chief Operating Officer named Sheryl Sandberg, but she has been too busy telling women how to treat other women, rather than actually running the company.

BARTIROMO: You mean "Lean In."

MCDOWELL: Yes, whatever it was --

BARTIROMO: "Lean In," yes.

MCDOWELL: Whatever hooey (ph) message that was.

BARTIROMO: By the way --

MCDOWELL: Entire book (ph).

BARTIROMO: -- as we've spoken before, if he doesn't want to step down, he's not going anywhere, he's got full voting control, Steve Forbes. People need to understand that when they buy Facebook shares.

FORBES: They know.

BARTIROMO: He's making all the decisions. Kurt (ph), thank you.

KNUDSEN (ph): Yes, his architecture in setting up that was brilliant. He's got control.

BARTIROMO: Apparently. Kurt Knudsen (ph), thank you so much. Coming up, new Russia probe bombshells, newly uncovered text messages - we told you they were coming, now we know. They are between FBI officials Peter Strzok and Lisa Page. They strongly suggest a coordination between President Obama's White House, former Senate democrats, and the CIA early on in the Russia Investigation. The outrage coming up this morning. Then I-Hop making the top five list of casual ding customers with the most loyal customers. But which one flies to number one? The big reveal coming up.

(BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Thursday. It is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right now, 7:30am on the east coast. Stocks are looking to rebound this morning. Check it out, Dow Industrials are up 70 points right now, S&P up 9, and the Nasdaq is up 43. This marks the final trading day of the month and the final trading day of the quarter.

The first quarter was a tough one for stocks. The Dow and S&P 500 on track for the first quarterly decline in more than two years. Stocks closed the day yesterday lower. The Nasdaq was the worst performer, down almost 1% on the session as technology once again took a hit. The Dow was down only nine points and the S&P down only seven yesterday.

Global markets are higher this morning. Take a look at European indices this morning, the FT-100, the (inaudible), and the Dax Index all up this morning. In Asia overnight stocks edged higher at the close, as you will see. The Shanghai Composite was the best performer there, up one and a quarter percent in China.

Technology was the big pressure on the market yesterday, but this morning we're looking at a relief rally underway. The biggest names in the sector all higher at the open today. As you can see, Facebook is up one and a quarter percent, and Netflix is up 1% as well.

New questions this morning over the collusion. This time it is against democrats. The shocking allegations revealed in new text messages. They show coordination between The White House and law enforcement agencies, President Obama's White House. Here's how House Intelligence Committee Chairmen Devin Nunes reacted last night.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

DEVIN NUNES, CHAIRMAN, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: The left continued to say that "This is Watergate," and "Trump's going to be impeached." They continued that. Well now this has effectively boomeranged on them.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: The fallout coming up this morning. And then play ball. It is opening day today for major league baseball. We have a look at the top matchups. All 30 clubs will be playing today. Plus flying high with customers. People love I-Hop right? But there is one place they actually love more. We have the top restaurant for customer loyalty coming up this morning.

Plus there's this, trading up, Carnival Cruise is offering a teenager a luxury trip in exchange for a Snapchat handle. We've got the story coming up. And then from the grid iron to the silver screen, details on Rob Gronkowski's new role in a Mel Gibson film. All those stories coming up, but first this top story this half an hour.

FBI fury over newly uncovered text messages. GOP Congressional investigators telling Fox News the text between Peter Strzok and Lisa Page strongly suggest coordination between officials in the Obama Administration, former Senate Democratic Leadership, the CIA, the FBI, and the Justice Department during the early stages of the Russia Investigation. Is anyone surprised?

In one of the text messages Strzok texts Page this, "Internal joint cyber CD Intel piece for D." This refers to former FBI Director James Comey. "Is the scene setter for Former Chief Of Staff under Obama, Denis McDonough's (ph) brief, Trainor the Head of the FBI Cyber Division directed all cyber info be pulled. I'd let Bill and Jim hammer it out first, though it would be best for D to have it before the Wednesday White House Session." So they had the meeting at The White House it appears. House Intelligence Committee Chiarman Devin Nunes has been leading the charge on this, and he reacted to what was revealed last night.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

DEVIN NUNES, CHAIRMAN, HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE The democrats appear like they weaponized to some degree the intelligence services by using the foreign intelligence surveillance apparatus in this country to go and target the opposition campaign, is totally unacceptable.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Chief Political Correspondent for the Washington Examiner and Fox News Contributor Byron York. Byron, great to see you.

BYRON YORK, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Remember during the election when Hillary Clinton always used to say "Seventeen agencies said there was collusion between Trump and Russia" Remember that B.S.? They were -- what do you think these texts tell us?

YORK: Well, these texts are important for two reasons, for what they say and for the fact that the Justice Department hid important facts about them from Congress. On what they say, one of the things we've been trying to find out for quite a while is about the Trump dossier, about the allegations in the Trump dossier, how high in the Obama Administration did knowledge of those allegations go?

And what these texts show is that shortly after the FBI formally began its TrumpRussia, counter intelligence investigations -- this is in August of 2016, shortly after the investigation gets underway, they are talking -- Strzok and Page are talking about briefing Dennis McDonough who was President Obama's Chief of Staff.

Now remember, we have heard democrats being critical of President Trump for keeping tabs on the FBI investigation. Here at the very least it appears The White House may have been keeping tabs on the FBI investigation.

BARTIROMO: We know the FBI and the DOJ are now officially under investigation for the FISA abuses in the Russia probe as well. That was of course made earlier this month by House Intel Committee. DOJ's Inspector General Michael Horowitz announced yesterday he's reviewing what FBI officials and the Justice Departtment knew when they asked a federal court to let them spy on Carter Page during the presidential campaign.

So Byron, basically they created this narrative that there was collusion between Trump and the Russians. Then they paid for -- the Democratic Party paid for the dossier with unverified stuff. They take it to the FISA court. They get a warrant based on that unverified dossier to spy on the Trump campaign all during the election. It's extraordinary to me that he actually still won. I mean, it is.

YORK: When you hear the Inspector General or you hear republicans talking about investigating FISA abuse, they're really investigating the dossier. If you look at the charging -- if you look at the description of how the Inspector General is going to investigate, it's about this dossier, how did they get it, what was the role of the former British spy, Christopher Steele in doing it, why did they agree to pay Christopher Steele to work on this at the same time Steele was being paid by the Clinton campaign, and finally how did they use it in the FISA warrant application?

But one last thing about the Justice Department not being open about this, on these Strzok Page texts, they sent a lot of the texts to Congress, but a lot of them -- parts of them were redacted. They were blacked out. And the FBI said "Look, these two people were having an affair. There's a lot of personal information in the texts. We're going to cover that up. You don't need to see that." Congress said "Fine, we're not investigating their relationship." But what they have now discovered is that the FBI and the Justice Department also covered up important facts like Dennis McDonough's name. So they learned that, wow, there's an Obama White House official involved here and that was previously redacted -

FORBES: Well Byron -

BARTIROMO: That's absolutely right, and they also redacted the texts about wanting to go to a party with the FISA judge. Let's not forget that, Judge Contreras. Go ahead, Steve.

FORBES: Byron, one of the things the other side has been good at is muddying the waters, making it complicated so people can't grasp it in a tweet, you might say. Where does this go from here? Will we get a special prosecutor? Is Sessions going to step up to the plate and make sure justice is done here? A lot of revelations. What happens next? What's the next step?

YORK: Well the first thing that's going to happen, probably, will be the release of this inspector general's report that you've heard about. It's not an investigation into the TrumpRussia investigation, but it is an investigation into how Andrew McCabe, James Comey, the FBI handled the Hillary Clinton investigation and, boy, we know there's plenty of questions about what they did there. So look for that to come out basically at the same time as James Comey's national book tour.

FORBES: Just a coincidence.

YORK: So we'll - you will find out about that. This new inspector general investigation just announced into the dossier and the handling of the dossier, you know what happens with those. They take a long time. It will eventually come out but not for probably at least a year.

MCDOWELL: Byron, I want to add to that. The Inspector General has limited power to compel the testimony from people who no longer work within the government like Andrew McCabe.

YORK: Right.

BARTIROMO: And Jim Comey.

MCDOWELL: and Jim Comey. Sp do you think we still get a Special Counsel on this?

YORK: Yes, you have given the Trey Gowdy argument in favor of a Special Counsel, because look at all the people involved. They can only investigate people who are employees of the Justice Department. James Comey is no longer an employee, neither is Andrew McCabe. Christopher Steele never was. What about Fusion GPS? All these people who can't be investigated. That is the strongest argument for a Special Counsel, but I have to say, I haven't seen any indication right now that that's going to happen.

FORBES: What's Sessions' hang up on this?

BARTIROMO: Right.

YORK: There are a lot of republicans who are just opposed philosophically to the idea of Special Counsel. They believe - and they're correct, that it results in mission creep. They go forever. They go all over the place. I mean we're seeing that in the Mueller campaign, because -

(CROSSTALK)

YORK: -- but the reason this one's gone off the track, the current one, is because the parameters were not there. If you set specific parameters on what you can and cannot do when you appoint that Special Counsel, you can prevent the abuses. But the number two in the Justice Department didn't do that, which is why Mueller is going all over the place.

BARTIROMO: Well that's right, but let me just add to that because the initial mandate here, Byron, was that Bob Mueller looks at collusion with the Trump campaign or collusion between Trump and Russia. So why is the investigation still going on? If we know that this is a whole bunch of nothing, and that they created this whole narrative to keep Donald Trump out of The White House, why is Robert Mueller continuing this charade?

YORK: Well --

FORBES: Because the guardrails were not put in. They said it, but they didn't make it in a specific way, this is what you can and cannot do.

BARTIROMO: So in other words, he can go into obstruction of justice, he can go wherever he wants.

FORBES: He can investigate us if he wants.

BARTIROMO: Right.

YORK: We should always be careful in talking about Mueller, because there's a lot of stuff we don't know. But on the collusion front, look at this, he has charged several people who are very high in the Trump campaign, Paul Manafort, Michael Flynn, Richard Gates -- people who if there had been a scheme to conspire with the Russians, they would have been involved, they would have known about it. And yet they've been charged with criminal acts, none of which involved any collusion.

FORBES: Exactly.

YORK: So that's a good reason for us to believe that maybe it's not going to happen. And as far as obstruction is concerned, we know he is investigating that, but we also know one other thing. As far as President Trump personally is concerned, he's the president. He's not going to be charged with a crime and dragged into a courtroom. If anything happens, it would be the political process of impeachment and all these legal arguments we hear about, they're not really going to be as important as the political argument of president Trump.

BARTIROMO: All right real quick, Byron, we've got to jump, but do you think anybody goes to jail over the massive abuse of power?

YORK: Anybody in the FBI, it would be very unlikely. I think people on Capitol Hill want to expose this. They want to find out what happened. I don't think they want to send anybody behind bars. They want to find out what happened right now.

BARTIROMO: Byron, we'll leave it there. Good to see you, thanks so much.

YORK: Thank you Maria.

BARTIROMO: Byron York joining us there. Coming up, play ball, it's baseball's opening day today, but the hope for all 50 teams to hit the diamond today are dashed. We'll tell you why. Then, from New England to Hollywood? Rob Gronkowski may be sharing the big screen with Mel Gibson. We'll be back in a moment with that.

(BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The Nobel Prize winner and human rights activist is back home in Pakistan for the first time since she was shot by Taliban militants. Cheryl Casone with the story. Cheryl?

CASONE: That's right Maria, Malala Yousafzai he was shot in 2012 by militants who were angry over her support for teaching girls. Just hours after she arrived in Pakistan, she met with Pakistan's Prime Minister and said she was excited to be back in her country.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

MALALA YOUSAFZAI: (Inaudible) in 2007 to 2009, and then seeing how many (inaudible) in our society and how we can fight against those challenges.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

CASONE: Well Malala adding how she always planned to come home after having to leave Pakistan for medical treatment. Her visit is expected to last four days. Well, the Saudi Arabian stock market is joining FTSE Russell's emerging market index. That's going to start March of next year. The move is expected to draw billions of dollars of foreign portfolio investment into the country. Saudi Arabia's Finance Minister was on the show earlier this week, talking about the country's reforms launched by the crown prince Mohammed Bin Salman.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

MOHAMMED AL-JADAAN, FINANCE MINISTER, SAUDI ARABIA: We are at the stage where we moved from planning over the past two years to execution. So there is significant positive momentum now, where the economy is going.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

CASONE: Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia is expected to unveil rules by the end of June to prevent large share price drops in newly listed companies. Officials say this is the final regulatory step for the listing of Saudi Aramco. And then there's this, the winner of the hunger games, not the movie, but the casual restaurant with the most loyal customers is Buffalo Wild Wings. Others in the top 10 include Applebee's, Hooters, and Beef 'O' Brady's. Buffalo Wild Wings was acquired by the private equity firm that also owns Arby's, by the way, Roark Capital, back in November.

Then there is this. A Virginian teen is taking a cruise of a lifetime for the small price of Snapchat handle. Fifteen year old Darian Lipscomb recreated the handle at @Carnival Cruise years ago, because he was a super fan of the cruise line. Well Carnival wanted it. They went to prospect to find Darian, even putting up a giant billboard, asking for help When they did find him, they offered him a trip worth $5,000 on their latest vessel, the Carnival Horizon. He's taking his entire family, Maria. There is shares of Carnival year-to-date (ph). It's down a buck 09 yesterday. All right, I've got to say I would have taken the money and I don't know, invested it for college, butt that's just me, bur he took the cruise.

BARTIROMO: He wanted the cruise. Hey, he's smart to get that handle.

FORBES: What if they had investeed in Facebook, you know?

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: Or Snapchat.

FORBES: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We will take a break. When we come back, Gronk (ph) the movie star? The New England Patriots' tight end may be in a new action film with Mel Gibson. We've got the details right after this.

(BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Well move over Michael Jordan, here comes Lebron. Jared has the story right now. Hey Jared.

JARED MAX, FBN SPORTS REPORTER: Good morning, Maria. More folks saying "Lebron, is he the best ever?" Every regular season NBA game Lebron has played since January 6th, 2007, he has scored at least 10 points a game.

Last night, this dunk by Lebron against the Charlotte Hornets pushed his point total to 10 points for the game. Ten, the milestone marker, 866 consecutive games Lebron has scored double digit points. This ties an NBA record shared by Michael Jordan, who happens to own the Hornets team that Lebron of the Cavaliers beat last night. Lebron finished with 41 points, which is 15 fewer than the 56 scored by Minnesota's Karl-Anthony Towns last night, a (inaudible) record.

Hey, happy Hope-ening Day. Every team is in first place this morning, before the baseball season begins 12:40 eastern. Earliest opening day ever, March 29th. Commissioner Rob Manfred spoke Maria Bartiromo earlier this week. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

ROB MANFRED, COMMISSIONER, MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL: We think getting back to the tradition of everybody playing on opening day is an exciting thing for the sport. I think it gives us an opportunity to own Thursday, make opening day into the national holiday that it should be.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

MAX: Yes, alll 30 MLB teams were scheduled to play today, but the Reds game in Cincinnati against the Nationals postponed because of a rainy forecast. They'll make it up tomorrow, first game 12:40 in Miami between the Cubs and the Marlins.

History will be made in the NFL next season, the L.A. Rams are going to have two male cheerleaders. While the Indianapolis Colts and the Baltimore Ravens do have men who perform stuns with the female cheerleaders, Quinton Peron and Napolean Jinnies will actually be cheerleaders dancing part of the squad of 40 with the Rams.

Speaking of dancing, we've seen Patriots' tight end Rob Gronkowski's moves. Last week he was on the shoulders of Shaquille O'Neal. Now he's going to make another movie. Gronk reportedly has signed on for an acting role in an upcoming action movie that is going to star Mel Gibson, and the movie is titled "Boss Level." He was just in a movie last year too, "Clapper," too. So Gronk's doing it all. After the Super Bowl,l he made comments that made you think is he looking to retire? Maybe he sees that there's a future outside of football that has nothing to do with getting your head knocked around.

BARTIROMO: Yes, would that get you to go see the movie?

MCDOWELL: If Mel Gibson isn't in it, I would go see it.

MAX: That's not going to happen with them together (ph).

MCDOWELL: I would probably go -

BARTIROMO: Why?

MCDOWELL: How Mel Gibson has a career left, I have no idea.

BARTIROMO: Really?

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: Given his horrible behavior, remember the drunk driving charge -

BARTIROMO: Oh, right.

MCDOWELL: -- the horrible slurs

(CROSSTALK)

MAX: -- it was just like gosh (ph).

MCDOWELL: -- the way he speaks to women, the rants that were caught on audio. By the way, Gronk, I get to tell my one Gronk story. I saw him wearing a Spongebob backpack down in Miami once.

MAX: He is a Spongebob backpack.

BARTIROMO: That's so funny.

MCDOWELL: Because of his size, I bet he photographs very well on the big screen.

MAX: Yes, in this country, there are numerous second acts, third acts -- tenth acts. You're never down forever. Lebron James' acts (ph) is still pretty good -

MCDOWELL: Look at Roseanne (ph).

MAX: -- (inaudible) what he's got too.

FORBES (ph): Remember, Trump went after Rosanne in that first debate in 2015 when you called out statements about women, he said "Oh Rosanne," everyone laughed. Now they're best buddies.

BARTIROMO: Wow interesting, Jared, thank you. Jared Max, catch the sports sports reports and Fox News headlines 24/7, Sirius XM115. Still ahead, we head to outer space. That's next.

END

urn:contentItem:5S09-SBD1-JB20-G2BG-00000-00Facebook Privacy Settings; Mark Zuckerberg to go in Front of Congress; Trump in Ohio for Infrastructure; Gronkowski's Next Movie; Obama's White House Coordinated With Russia?; Carnival Cruise Wants 15 Year Old Boy's Snapchat Handle; Lebron James Averages 10 Points Per Game Since 20072018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:31ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTSteve Forbes, Lindsey Bell, Kurt Knusen (ph)NEWSFinancial032902cb.231Facebook Privacy Settings; Mark Zuckerberg to go in Front of Congress; Trump in Ohio for Infrastructure; Gronkowski's Next Movie; Obama's White House Coordinated With Russia?; Carnival Cruise Wants 15 Year Old Boy's Snapchat Handle; Lebron James Averages 10 Points Per Game Since 2007Maria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Ed Rollins, Cheryl Casone, Byron York, Jared Max

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning. Everybody thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. It is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right now, 7 am on the east coast. Trouble for technology, shares of several big tech companies under pressure yesterday, and there's fears of a regulatory crack down.

Both Facebook and Twitter are in bear market territory while Alphabet, Amazon, Netflix are in correction territory. The slide comes amid fears of a regulatory crack down following Facebook's personal data scandal.

But, the stocks are bouncing this morning we should tell you. The concerns weighed on the major average yesterday. The Dow, the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq, all on pace for the worst March in nearly 20 years across (ph) the month and the quarter and today.

Futures this morning show a rally at the start of trading this morning, Dow Industrials up 70 points right now, a third of a percent. S&P is up 10 points, at the third of a percent and the Nasdaq is up 40 points, that's two thirds of one percent.

In Europe, stocks are higher a across the board. Take a look, FT-100, TechCrunch (ph), DAX Index, all up this morning. In Asia overnight, green across the board there as well. Shanghai composite, the best performer in China, up one and a quarter percent.

Rebuilding America, President Trump is set to pitch his highly anticipated infrastructure plan. He's going to Ohio to do that today in an effort to fulfill a campaign promise.

(BEGIN VIDEOCLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, UNITED STATES PRESIDENT: We're going to make our infrastructure modernized, and we're really way behind schedule. We're way behind other countries. We also led the many way for many, many years. Then a number of decades ago it slowed down, and over the last eight years and 15 years, to be honest, it's come to a halt.

(END VIDEOCLIP)

BARTIROMO: What to expect from the big push coming up this morning. Collusion in the Capitol, newly uncovered texts show possible coordination between the Obama administration, the CIA, the FBI, the Justice Department, and the Democratic Leadership over the Russia investigation. They were all in on it. The shocking revelations coming up.

Let's make a deal. Nissan reportedly in talks to merge with Renault. We are breaking down the deal for the two auto companies, which have been partnered side by side for some time now. And not funny, comedian Jim Carrey under fire again this morning after his latest painting targets the president's son. The outrage coming up this morning.

And then problems in the bedroom, why nearly one-third of married couples are ready to hit the snooze button on their sleeping arrangements. All those stories coming up this morning. Joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McdDowell, Forbes Media Chairman and the former Republican President Trump Candidate himself, Steve Forbes is here. CRFA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell as well. Good morning, everybody. Great to see you.

DAGEN MCDOWELL: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good morning, good morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Here on a day that we're ending the quarter, which is going to be a pretty good quarter for earnings, by the way.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CRFA: It's going to be a great aware for earnings, not so much for the performance of the stock market. But once earnings start being released, April 13th, JP Morgan really kicks it all off. We should see investors feel reassured about the fundamentals of corporate America.

BARTIROMO: Because you're expecting 16.5% earnings growth in the S&P 500 in the first quarter, right?

MCDOWELL: I think one thing weighing on the market, and we were talking about this in the break, and we mentioned it in the last hour. It's not just Facebook and regulatory risk at some of these technology companies. We'll also look at Tesla. I think Tesla's stock fell more than 7.5% just yesterday. The unsecured bonds that mature in 2025, you mentioned this, fell to 86 cents on dollar. Although they recovered two cents of that 88 cents before ticking up to that. That is a real concern with the burn rate. Tesla was $1 billion a quarter recently. They're trying to get production rolling of the model 3. That's a real concern. Again I think that is another canary that we need to watch.

BARTIROMO: You're absolutely right.

FORBES: Uncertainty about a trade war too.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: Which thankfully it looks like it may be tamping down a little bit.

BARTIROMO: The trade war worries?

FORBES: Worries --

BARTIROMO: Yes. On your point, Dagen, cover story on the business section, Tesla, first it was the stock that traded down. Now we're worried about the bonds, because that's really showing liquid at this worries.

MCDOWELL: We're nerds. We watch the debt. The equity doesn't really tell you the story. Again financial crisis in - leading up to 2008, it was all in and in the bonds for two years before the market really collapsed.

BARTIROMO: I've got to give a shout out to Zero Hedge, they did a very good job on this a couple of days ago before this really came out. Now we're seeing it all over the place. urn:contentItem:5WB8-DFB1-JBHT-D39G-00000-00Facebook purge reignites censorship claims2019-05-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:46:31ZLexisNexisFacebook purge reignites censorship claimsMelissa QuinnWashington, D.C.FULL TEXT

Facebook’s ban of users Alex Jones of Infowars and Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam has reignited claims of social media censorship, demonstrating the thin boundary Silicon Valley must negotiate between free speech and harmful content.

The expulsion of the two, along with far-right political commentator Milo Yiannopoulos and four other incendiary posters, was one of the broadest steps the Menlo Park, Calif.-based company has taken to punish online provocateurs. Facebook attributed the decision to its long-standing policies on acceptable posts.

“We’ve always banned individuals or organizations that promote or engage in violence and hate, regardless of ideology,” a Facebook spokesman said. “The process for evaluating potential violators is extensive, and it is what led us to our decision to remove these accounts.”

Social media's biggest players have struggled for years to balance the proliferation of online hate and false content with a desire, and a financial incentive, to permit free speech. Some lawmakers see Facebook's action as a much-needed step toward rooting out racism and xenophobia.

[Opinion: Facebook doesn’t have to be a forum for open speech, but it should be]

Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., a leading voice on digital privacy, said a portion of the Communications Decency Act he authored two decades ago that provides a legal shield to websites publishing third-party content is tailored so that companies don't assume responsibility for all posts by merely policing the most extreme.

“I wrote Section 230 so Facebook and other companies can take down bad actors without being saddled with frivolous lawsuits," Wyden tweeted in response to Facebook's decision. "Platforms need to be much more vigilant about weeding out hate. This is a start."

The move nonetheless opens Mark Zuckerberg's company to claims that liberal-leaning employees are quashing opinions with which they disagree, an argument made by conservatives ever since social media platforms began trying to weed out content posted by agents from Russia and other hostile nations to influence U.S. voters.

Intelligence officials in the U.S. have said the Kremlin used such tactics to promote President Trump's candidacy in 2016, an assessment backed up in a recent report from special counsel Robert Mueller, who was tasked with investigating whether the campaign knowingly cooperated.

[Related: Facebook bans white nationalist speech]

“Once you start banning people for speech, inevitably you’re picking and choosing which speech you approve, and we don’t believe the social media companies should be trusted to do that,” said Dan Gainor, vice president of the Media Research Center’s TechWatch. “They have policies that are liberal, staff that are liberal, and inevitably we think conservatives are the ones who suffer for that.”

“Censoring people is like eating peanuts,” he added. “Once you eat one, you just can’t stop.”

Chief among Facebook’s critics is President Trump, who tweeted in the wake of its announcement that he is monitoring and watching “the censorship of AMERICAN CITIZENS on social media platforms.”

“This is the United States of America — and we have what’s known as FREEDOM OF SPEECH!” he tweeted.

The president warned in subsequent posts that social media is “getting worse and worse for conservatives” and signaled support for one of the people kicked off Facebook, right-wing internet personality Paul Joseph Watson.

Joining the president in his attack on Facebook was his eldest son, Donald Trump Jr., who accused the tech giant of mounting a “censorship campaign” that could result in platforms systematically purging conservatives.

“The purposeful and calculated silencing of conservatives by [Facebook] & the rest of the Big Tech monopoly men should terrify everyone,” Trump Jr. tweeted.

But Paul Barrett, deputy director of the New York University Stern Center for Business and Human Rights, said Facebook “hesitated for a long time” before its action.

“I’m sure they don’t relish doing it, but eventually if someone is repeatedly violating the standards you’ve set out as governing behavior in your privately owned platform, you’re going to bid that person farewell,” Barrett said.

Facebook’s issues, he said, are symptoms of its reach and influence, and have been exacerbated by its own technologies that boost widely shared posts.

“The extremist and sensationalistic and conspiracy-oriented expressions of people like Alex Jones, at least in part, reflect Alex Jones’ understanding that his posts will get more circulation on Facebook and on Twitter because of their very nature,” Barrett said. “That’s because of the algorithms Facebook and Twitter use that encourage sharing of sensationalistic material, because that keeps people’s attention, and attention is what Facebook sells to its advertisers and that’s the business model.”

Jones, a 45-year-old community college dropout, stirred controversy when he pantomimed shooting Mueller and was sued by parents of some of the 20 children killed in a December 2012 massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., over his claims the shooting was staged. In 2002, he wrote a book linking the George W. Bush administration to what he said was a conspiracy behind the 9/11 terrorist attacks.

To address hate and fearmongering on Facebook, some lawmakers have suggested Congress could step in, which Barrett warned could lead to government overreach.

Lawmakers' criticisms of Facebook and other platforms reached a fever pitch in March after a gunman whom police said killed 50 in an attack on two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, livestreamed the shooting.

The 17-minute video was flagged by a user but remained on Facebook for roughly 30 minutes before it was taken down. Facebook subsequently removed 1.5 million videos of the massacre in the first 24 hours, of which 1.2 million were blocked at upload.

The events prompted the House Judiciary Committee to hold a hearing last month on hate speech that included representatives from Facebook and Google. Republicans used the session to accuse tech companies of censoring conservatives, while Democrats noted the First Amendment prohibits the government, not private companies, from restricting freedom of speech.

The potential for federal involvement in content regulation is a “prime reason why Facebook, Twitter, YouTube need to devote a ton of resources right now to figuring out how to better govern themselves,” Barrett said.

He believes social media companies need to invest more in algorithms that identify false material, backed up by staff who understand the affairs of other nations. Facebook has done both, but Zuckerberg has welcomed more regulation, arguing that social media companies shouldn't make such sweeping decisions on their own.

Gainor, however, wants Facebook and others to “embrace the First Amendment, not to embrace global censorship.”

“Freedom of speech is uncomfortable sometimes,” he said. “Ultimately, the way to look at this is people should be able to determine what they want to see, not Facebook determining what they want to see.”

[03:00:00] (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MICHAEL HOLMES, CNN HOST: Facebook fights back. The social network says it has removed dozens of fake accounts that attempted to interfere in U.S. politics.

Crews making gains against those deadly wildfires ravaging California, but harsh weather conditions still causing problems.

And a gun rights group in the U.S. pushes for do-it-yourself firearms leading to a debate over free speech versus public safety.

And welcome to our viewers joining us from all around the world. I'm Michael Holmes, and this is CNN Newsroom.
